Description: Hematite cylinder seal; the design may orignally have consisted of two suppliant goddesses facing each other one with one either side of a three-line inscription. The inscription was erased and the king with a mace was cut facing right, to a slightly larger scale than the goddesses; a crescent above a spade and a star above a lightning fork were added in the field between the figures and a three-line inscription was added behind the goddesses. Still later the first two lines of the inscription were obliterated by the cutting of two "bow-legged dwarfs" tete-beche. Only the third line of the inscription is partially legible.
Bibliographic references: Collon 1986a / Catalogue of the Western Asiatic Seals in the British Museum: Cylinder Seals III: Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian Periods (581)
Leichty E et al 1988a / Catalogue of the Babylonian Tablets in the British Museum, volume VIII: Tablets from Sippar 3 (p.300)
Acquisition name: From: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
